docs.lead_paragraph: MANY firefighters in Shelton are angry about what they believe to be targeting of their vehicles for tickets by a few disgruntled police officers. But the conflict goes back several years, say officials, and involves not only the two departments but also the mayor's office. Accusations, official complaints and at least one lawsuit have resulted. While most officials maintain that the troubles have had no direct impact on service to the city, everyone agrees that reconciliation is needed in order for Shelton to move forward.

headline.main: Police and Firefighters At Odds in Shelton

docs.abstract: Article traces long history of conflict between police and firefighters in Shelton, Conn; firefighters claim their vehicles are being targeted by disgruntled police officers (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: More than 200,000 Medicare beneficiaries will have to find new health insurance next year because they are in health maintenance organizations that are cutting back their Medicare operations. The Clinton Administration told H.M.O.'s that they would not be allowed to increase premiums or cut benefits for the elderly.

docs.lead_paragraph: JOHN REGAN, a retired Bell Atlantic employee, wanted to join a health maintenance organization near his home in Centerville, Mass., on Cape Cod. But the H.M.O. said no -- he lived in the wrong zip code. ''The health care field today is a very confusing one,'' Mr. Regan said.

headline.main: So Far, 'Medicare Plus Choice' Is Minus Most of the Options

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: Oxford Health Plans, one of the biggest managed care companies in the Northeast, said yesterday that it was dropping coverage for more than 26,000 elderly members of its Medicare health maintenance organizations in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. The cancellations, mainly in five suburban counties north of New York City, take effect on Jan. 1. The action by Oxford, together with similar recent announcements by three other big insurance companies, brings the number of consumers in the three states who will be dropped by Medicare H.M.O.'s by the end of the year to 35,000. It raises the national total to about 250,000, or about 4 percent of the 6.6 million people now enrolled in Medicare H.M.O.'s.

headline.main: Oxford to Drop Coverage for 26,000 in Medicare H.M.O.'s

docs.lead_paragraph: GOLDSTEIN-Murray. The Officers and Members of the New York Joint Board, Unite express deep sense of loss at the death of Murray Goldstein, former Manager of the New York Joint Board, ACWA, ACTWU, Unite. He served as Vice President of ACTWU, Vice President of the Sidney Hillman Health Center, Director of the Amalgamated Bank of New York, and Director of the Amalgamated Life Insurance Company. He also served as Chairman of the Workmens Circle, the National Board of Histadrud, American Labor ORT and the Jewish Labor Committee. Murray retired from the New York Joint Board in 1981. His kindness and inspiration will be deeply missed. Our sympathies are extended to his wife Gladyce, his children Bruce, Donald, Stanley and Robert, their spouses, his seven grandchildren, and two sisters.

docs.lead_paragraph: Game Of The Week Monday 8:20 P.M. Vikings 4-0 Packers 4-0 Green Bay's Mike Holmgren has everything a coach could want: a Super Bowl ring, a great quarterback and a terrific front office. But there is one thing he does not have--a winning record against Minnesota's Dennis Green. In fact, Green is the only coach in the N.F.C. Central with a winning record (7-5) against Holmgren. The Packers are impressive -- no, scary -- at home. They've won 25 straight at Lambeau Field and 18 straight against the division at home. Their last home loss to a division opponent? The Vikings in 1993. It is an omen the Vikings are well aware of. Green knows how to beat the Packers, and Minnesota has what Green Bay does not: a running game. Robert Smith has 384 yards rushing on 75 carries. He's the difference. Vikings, 27-26 SUNDAY 1 P.M. Miami (3-0) at Jets (1-2) Many are starting to believe that Miami is a legitimate Super Bowl contender. Jimmy Johnson is one of the best evaluators of talent the game has ever seen, and he has built a fast, tough defense that allows a conference-low 241.3 yards a game. That's what this game will come down to - Miami simply has the better defense. Vinny Testaverde will start at quarterback again this week for the Jets. Curtis Martin and Keyshawn Johnson will keep the game close. Dophins, 16-10 Carolina (0-3) at Atlanta (2-1) Carolina is in deep trouble because this game has loss written all over it. The biggest reason is that Atlanta Coach Dan Reeves always beats the teams he should. Atlanta has won 7 of its past 9 games by beating up on the dregs of the National Football League. Atlanta quarterback Chris Chandler set a team record last week with a touchdown pass in 15 straight games. This will be 16, and the Falcons will win easily. Falcons, 30-21 Dallas (2-2) at Washington (0-4)

docs.lead_paragraph: House and Senate negotiators agreed today to require most Federal health plans to cover prescription contraceptives for women, giving an unusual victory on Capitol Hill to advocates of abortion rights. But the future of the measure was in doubt because it was attached to a spending bill that includes a controversial provision regarding the Federal Election Commission. That provision could scuttle the spending bill, which would finance the Treasury Department and the Postal Service and which must still be approved by the House and Senate.

headline.main: Abortion Rights Forces Win Rare Victory on Capitol Hill

docs.abstract: House and Senate negotiators agree to require most Federal health plans to cover prescription contraceptives for women, giving an unusual victory on Capitol Hill to advocates of abortion rights; but future of measure is in doubt because it is attached to spending bill that includes controversial provision regarding Federal Election Commission; that provision could scuttle spending bill, which would finance Treasury Dept and Postal Service; abortion rights advocates are promoting contraception as part of new strategy intended to counter abortion opponents' portrayal of them as extremists; in fact, abortion rights activists are trying to use issue of contraception to cast foes of abortion as extremists because many also oppose birth control (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: They came on foot, by bus and in crammed taxis. One man even traveled 20 blocks in his motorized wheelchair. The men and women of the Woodstock Hotel returned home yesterday, toting their belongings in large green trash bags and tattered cardboard boxes. Finally, the exile was over for 250 low-income elderly people who were hoping to return to their former lives and all the essentials left behind on the morning of July 21, when a temporary elevator tower at the half-completed Conde Nast building in Times Square collapsed. A portion of the scaffolding crashed through the Woodstock's roof, killing an 85-year-old resident, Thereza Feliconio, and forcing the evacuation of the others who lived there. While many found things yesterday just as they had left them, others discovered unexpected improvements and a few disorienting changes.

headline.main: Exile Ends for Residents of a Times Square Hotel

docs.abstract: Residents return to Woodstock Hotel in Times Square, which has been closed since July 21 when temporary elevator tower at Conde Nast building collapsed onto hotel's roof, killing woman; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Health maintenance organizations, once thought to be the hope for the future of Medicare, said today that they would drop tens of thousands of beneficiaries next year, in part because the Clinton Administration had refused to let them raise premiums or cut prescription drug coverage for the elderly. Insurance executives said that health plans were withdrawing from 300 counties in 18 states because medical costs were higher than expected, while Medicare payments were lower than anticipated.

headline.main: H.M.O.'s Are Retreating From Medicare, Citing High Costs

docs.lead_paragraph: As investigations expand into possible problems with medical care in city jails, including several deaths, top New York City health officials have acknowledged that they have had trouble monitoring the jail system's shift to managed care. The health officials said that they were scrambling to set up a better system for supervising medical treatment on Rikers Island, and that they were demanding more medical services from the contractor, St. Barnabas Hospital in the Bronx, to keep it from earning excessive profits on the three-year, $342 million contract.

headline.main: Officials Scrambling to Assess Managed Health Care in Jails

docs.abstract: Top New York City health officials, as investigations expand into possible problems with medical care in city jails, including several deaths, have acknowledged that they have had trouble monitoring jail system's shift to managed care; say that they are scrambling to set up better system for supervising medical treatment on Rikers Island and are demanding more medical services from contractor, St Barnabas Hospital in Bronx, to keep it from earning excessive profits on three year, $342 million contract (M)
